question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Tom Fuller's NCAA basketball league affiliation in 1990?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Here is a potential Wikipedia entry that presents comprehensive evidence for the statement:

Tom Fuller

Tom Fuller is a former American college basketball player who played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. College Career

Fuller played college basketball for Oklahoma State University from 1953 to 1954. [1] During his time at Oklahoma State, the team was a member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I, which is the highest level of college athletics in the United States. [2]

NCAA Division I Membership

Oklahoma State University's men's basketball team has been a member of the NCAA Division I since the league's inception in 1953. [3] As a player for Oklahoma State during the 1953-1954 season, Fuller was a part of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. References:

[1] Oklahoma State University Athletics. (n.d.). 1953-54 Men's Basketball Roster. Retrieved from <https:\/\/okstate.com\/sports\/2019\/6\/27\/1953-54-mens-basketball-roster.aspx>

[2] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ncaa.org\/about\/resources\/media-center\/ncaa-101\/division-i>

[3] NCAA.org. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Membership History. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ncaa.org\/about\/resources\/research\/division-i-membership-history>

This entry presents evidence that Tom Fuller played college basketball for Oklahoma State University from 1953 to 1954, and that Oklahoma State was a member of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during that time.
content.source_2:
What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around it, exploring the temporal implications of Tom Fuller's remarkable journey. Title: The Timeless Court

In the spring of 2034, the NCAA Division I women's basketball league was abuzz with excitement. The season was about to conclude, and teams were vying for a spot in the coveted championship tournament. Amidst the frenzy, a peculiar phenomenon occurred. Tom Fuller, a former college basketball player from Oklahoma State, who had last stepped onto the court in 1954, suddenly materialized on the sidelines of a women's basketball game. At first, everyone thought it was some kind of prank or a clever marketing stunt. But as Tom began to warm up, his movements fluid and effortless, it became clear that this was no joke. The 81-year-old man, who had been presumed long retired, was about to take the court by storm. As the clock struck 7:04 PM on April 7, 2034, Tom Fuller made his debut in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. The crowd was stunned, the players bewildered, and the coaches scrambling to adjust their strategies. How could a man from a bygone era, who had never played against women, suddenly dominate the court? Tom's first game was a blur of fast breaks, three-pointers, and defensive stops. He moved with a speed and agility that belied his age, leaving opponents and teammates alike in awe. The league was thrown into chaos as Tom's presence disrupted the established pecking order. Coaches scrambled to find ways to counter his unorthodox style, which blended vintage moves with an uncanny understanding of modern basketball. As the seasons unfolded, Tom became an unlikely sensation. Fans flocked to see him play, and his name was on everyone's lips. The NCAA struggled to keep up with the implications of his presence, as rules and regulations were rewritten to accommodate this temporal anomaly. Tom's four-year stint in the league was a whirlwind of excitement and controversy. He led his team to two championship titles, earning MVP honors both times. His influence extended beyond the court, as he inspired a new generation of players and coaches to rethink their approach to the game. On September 23, 2038, Tom Fuller played his final game in the NCAA Division I women's basketball league. As the buzzer sounded, he walked off the court, his eyes shining with a deep sense of satisfaction.
